text.headline: Orbital Sunrise
text.text:
Location: Soviet
Artists/Group: Alexei Arkhipovich Leonov (USSR cosmonaut, artist)
Technical Support: Soviet Space Program (Voskhod-2 mission team, OKB-1 Design Bureau)
Type: Drawing / Space-based artwork
Presentation/Audience: Originally a private act of artistic expression in orbit, the drawing was later preserved and exhibited on Earth. It was featured in the 2015 exhibition Cosmonauts: Birth of the Space Age at the Science Museum, London, where audiences could view the original sketch and archival footage of Leonov’s mission.

text.headline: The Moon Museum
text.text:
Location: America
Artists/Group: Forrest Myers (initiator) with Andy Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg, David Novros, Claes Oldenburg, and John Chamberlain
Technical Support: Engineers at Bell Laboratories (miniaturisation / etching of drawings onto ceramic wafer); anonymous engineer at Grumman Aircraft involved in placement on lunar module. Apollo 12
Type: Artworks designed to be sent to the Moon.
Presentation/Audience: Originally the work was never officially exhibited in space (and its actual presence on the Moon remains disputed). On Earth, editions of the wafer have been shown in museums (for example at the Museum of Modern Art, New York). The Museum of Modern Art The project raises questions about art, space exploration, institutional permission, clandestine practice, and how artworks engage with extreme environments beyond Earth.

text.headline: Fallen Astronaut
text.text:
Location: America
Artists/Group: Paul Van Hoeydonck (Belgian artist) NASA, United States
Technical Support: Apollo 15 mission crew (NASA, United States) Apollo 15
Type: Artworks designed to be sent to the Moon. Sculpture / Monument / Memorial Art
Presentation/Audience: The original sculpture remains on the Moon, visible only through archival photos and mission documentation. Its Earth-based replicas and later exhibitions have provoked discussion about authenticity, commemoration, and the ethics of art beyond Earth.

text.headline: Voyager Golden Record
text.text:
Location: America
Artists/Group: 1977 – present (Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 missions launched in September 1977; left the solar system in 2012 and 2018 respectively Concept initiated by Carl Sagan (astronomer) and the Voyager Interstellar Record Committee: Frank Drake, Ann Druyan, Timothy Ferris, Jon Lomberg, Linda Sagan, et al.
Technical Support: NASA / Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL); Cornell University; NASA Ames Research Center
Type: orbit art Interstellar message / science–art hybrid / sound-and-image archive
Presentation/Audience: On the Earth Museum Though the original records are now beyond human reach, replicas and digital editions have been displayed on Earth at the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, MoMA, and other institutions. The project continues to inspire audiences through exhibitions, documentaries, and the 2017 Voyager Golden Record: 40th Anniversary Edition reissue by Ozma Records.

text.headline: Satellite Arts Project
text.text:

Artists/Group: Sherrie Rabinowitz & Kit Galloway

References: Bureaud, Annick. "It's a Beautiful Name for a Satellite: Paradoxical Art Objects Somewhere between Politics and Poetics." Leonardo 54.1 (2021): 79-91.

text.headline: Orbital Reflector
text.text:
Location: Deployed from Vandenberg Air Force Base, California, USA
Artists/Group: Trevor Paglen (in collaboration with the Nevada Museum of Art)
Technical Support: Aerospace engineer team led by Global Western, in partnership with Spaceflight Industries; launch supported by SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket; Nevada Museum of Art provided institutional and curatorial backing
Type: Satellite Art / Space Sculpture / Public Art in Orbit
Presentation/Audience: Earth-based exhibition Orignally visible to the public with the naked eye. A reflective sculpture planned to unfold in orbit but failed to deploy.
References: Brownie, Barbara. Art in Orbit: Art Objects and Spaceflight. Bloomsbury Publishing, 2025. Print.p.30.

text.text:

text.headline: Tianshu Rocket

Presentation/Audience: Suborbital flight within Earth’s atmosphere; related video and documentation presented in exhibitions of Xu Bing’s space art projects in China. Installation view of "Xu Bing Tianshu" Rocket Crater. Red Brcik Museum, Beijing, 2021

text.headline: Moon Gallery
text.text:
Location: The Netherlands (headquarters and curatorial base, ESA–ESTEC, Noordwijk)
Artists/Group: Moon Gallery Foundation (founded by Dr. Nahum Anaya Calderón and Dr. Alexander Ponomarev) — a collective of international artists, designers, engineers, and scientists
Technical Support: European Space Agency (ESA) – European Space Research and Technology Centre (ESTEC); International Space Station National Lab; Nanoracks; Ramon Foundation; NASA (partnership for Ax-1 mission)
Type: Artworks designed to be sent to the Moon.
Presentation/Audience: Moon-based exhibition Moon Gallery for next generation By embedding art in space exploration, we hope to leave a cultural legacy that inspires dialogue, collaboration, and a sense of unity for generations to come.

text.headline: The Challenge (Вызов)
text.text:
Location: Russia
Artists/Group: Directed by Klim Shipenko; starring Yulia Peresild; produced by Channel One Russia and Roscosmos
Technical Support: Roscosmos (Russian Space Agency); International Space Station (ISS) crew
Type: On October 5 2021, the Russian space agency Roscosmos launched film director Klim Shipenko and actress Yulia Peresild to the International Space Station to shoot the feature film The Challenge—the first major motion picture filmed in space. Over twelve days aboard the ISS, they filmed scenes involving two Russian cosmonauts who also appeared in the movie. The story follows a doctor who must travel to space to save an astronaut’s life. The film premiered on April 20 2023 in Serbia and Russia.
Presentation/Audience: Space film / cinematic performance / collaborative art–science project

text.headline: Impossible object
text.text:
Location: Israel
Artists/Group: Prof. Yasmine Meroz and Liat Segal
Technical Support: Israeli Space Agency; Ramon Foundation; Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI); in collaboration with NASA and the ISS National Lab Impossible Object was activated and documented on the International Space Station by astronaut Eitan Stibe during mission AX-1, April 2022, as part of Rakia Art Mission. Axiom Mission 1 (Ax-1) was the first private astronaut mission on the International Space Station (ISS), a collaborative effort between SpaceX (shuttle) on behalf of Axiom Space in cooperation with NASA, in which four crew members conducted science, art, and outreach activities.
Type: Space Art / Kinetic Sculpture / Science-Art Collaboration
Presentation/Audience: Earth-based exhibition video video recording, scientific data, and photographic documentation have been exhibited in Isreal Museum. The artwork Impossible Object is no longer aboard the International Space Station. The mission lasted about 17 days, during which the kinetic experiment was conducted and documented in microgravity. After the mission ended, the physical components of the artwork returned to Earth with the crew.
